perturbation.original_text: 2.1 The Executive's employment with the Company will commence on the Commencement Date and shall continue, subject to the remaining terms of this Agreement, until terminated by either party giving the other the following minimum advance written notice: 2.1.1 6 weeks' notice; 2.1.2 such other longer period as required by law.
perturbation.changed_text: 2.1 The Executive's employment with the Company will commence on the Commencement Date and shall continue, subject to the remaining terms of this Agreement, until terminated by either party giving the other the following minimum advance written notice: 2.1.1 1 weeks' notice; 2.1.2 such other longer period as required by law.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the minimum notice period to 1 week creates a conflict with the Employment Rights Act 1996 in the UK, which stipulates longer minimum notice periods based on the length of service. For an employee with more than two years of service, the statutory minimum is two weeks, increasing by one week for each year of service up to a maximum of 12 weeks. Setting a fixed one-week notice period regardless of service duration violates this law.

perturbation.changed_text: 17.1 The Company may, in its sole and absolute discretion, terminate the Executive's employment under this Agreement at any time and with immediate effect by notifying the Executive that the Company is exercising its right under this clause 17 and that it will make a payment in lieu of notice ("PILON") to the Executive. The Executive's employment will terminate immediately and any PILON due to the Executive in accordance with the provisions of this clause 17 will be paid within 90 days. The PILON will be equal to 50% of the basic salary (as at the Termination Date) which the Executive would have been entitled to receive under this Agreement during the notice period referred to at clause 2 (or, if notice has already been given, during the remainder of the notice period) less deductions required by law.
perturbation.explanation: Extending the payment timeframe for PILON to 90 days and reducing the amount to 50% creates a contradiction. The UK law implies that PILON should be paid promptly (typically within a reasonable payroll cycle) and should cover the full salary entitlement for the notice period. Delaying payment significantly and reducing the amount could be seen as a breach of contract and potentially violate employment law principles regarding fair and timely payment of wages.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied terms of employment contract, general principles of UK employment law regarding wage payment

perturbation.original_text: 21. Post Termination Restrictions During the term of employment and for one (1) year thereafter, the Executive will not directly or indirectly, either themselves or through others, encourage or solicit any employee of the Company to leave the Company for any reason. This obligation shall not affect any responsibility the Executive has as an employee of the Company with respect to the bona fide hiring and firing of Company personnel.
perturbation.changed_text: 21. Post Termination Restrictions During the term of employment and for five (5) years thereafter, the Executive will not directly or indirectly, either themselves or through others, encourage or solicit any employee of the Company to leave the Company for any reason. This obligation shall not affect any responsibility the Executive has as an employee of the Company with respect to the bona fide hiring and firing of Company personnel.
perturbation.explanation: Extending the post-termination restriction to five years makes it likely to be considered an unreasonably long duration under UK law. Non-compete clauses and restrictions on soliciting employees are only enforceable to the extent that they are necessary to protect the employer's legitimate business interests and are reasonable in scope and duration. A five-year restriction is likely to be viewed as excessive, especially for a general restriction on soliciting any employee, regardless of their seniority or the potential impact on the company. UK courts tend to disfavor long and broad restrictive covenants.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Common law principles regarding the reasonableness of restrictive covenants in employment contracts (UK)
